text: Two people were killed and dozens of others were

wounded overnight in Russian attacks on 
Ukrainian port cities on the Black Sea.

And Israel's president 
addressed Congress yesterday.

Good morning, I'm Korva Coleman, from NPR 
News, and here are today's top stories:

Ukraine's military says at least 27 people have 
been wounded and one other person killed in

Russian attacks on Black Sea port cities. Russia 
is also warning commercial ships in the Black

Sea will be designated legitimate targets. 
NPR's Charles Maynes reports from Moscow:

"Russia's Defense Ministry says it will now 
regard all ships headed to Ukrainian ports as,

"potential carriers of military cargo and their 
home countries as direct allies of Kyiv in the

conflict." The warning came just days after 
Moscow pulled out of a U.N.-brokered grain deal

that had guaranteed the safe passage of Ukrainian 
exports through the Black Sea for much of the past

year. Russian President Vladimir Putin says he 
withdrew from the agreement over its failure to

remove sanctions-related barriers to Russian 
agricultural trade. Putin has also promised

Russia would re-enter the deal if and when those 
barriers are lifted. Ukraine and its Western

allies accuse the Kremlin of leveraging global 
food security in a bid for sanctions relief.
"Charles Maynes, NPR News, Moscow."

The National Weather Service continues to warn of 
relentless heat in the South and the West today.

Just over 100 million people in the U.S. are 
under some kind of heat advisory or warning.

Texas' abortion restrictions are being challenged 
in court. The Center for Reproductive Rights sued

Texas on behalf of 13 women who had pregnancy 
complications and were denied abortions. NPR's

Selena Simmons-Duffin reports they're asking 
for a pause on the ban for certain abortions:

"During hours of emotional testimony 
Wednesday, three women described how

Texas abortion laws delayed medically 
needed abortions, which led to negative

health outcomes. One developed sepsis after her 
water broke. Another traveled out of state to

ensure a healthy twin could survive. Attorneys 
defending the state bans say the case should

be dismissed and that the state is not to blame 
for these women's experiences. Texas Assistant

Attorney General Amy Pletscher asked each of 
the patients who took the stand this question:

'At any time, did Attorney General Paxton tell 
you that you couldn't receive an abortion?'

"She also asked if any of the patients 
had filed malpractice claims against

their doctors. After the two-day hearing 
ends, the judge could rule at any time.
"Selena Simmons-Duffin, NPR News, Austin, Texas."

Israeli President Isaac Herzog is working 
to reassure U.S. lawmakers of the strength

of Israeli democracy. He spoke to a 
joint meeting of Congress yesterday.

Herzog noted deep divisions within Israel 
over a proposed overhaul of that nation's

judiciary. Herzog also warned U.S. lawmakers 
about Iran's actions in the Middle East:

"Iran is building nuclear capabilities that pose 
a threat to the stability of the Middle East and

beyond. Every country or region controlled or 
infiltrated by Iran has experienced utter havoc."

Herzog's speech was boycotted by 
a group of left-wing Democrats.
They oppose Israel's treatment of Palestinians.
You're listening to NPR.
